pr_title: Add Collection of Comp Sci Bibliographies fetcher

timeline.message: Add Collection of Comp Sci Bibliographies fetcher

timeline.author: Siedlerchr

timeline.bodyText: Please add an empty line before
timeline.author: koppor
koppor

timeline.bodyText:
Can XMLUtil print to a log file?
Then one could use LOGGER.debug(...)
The current solution is also OK for me.
timeline.author: koppor

timeline.bodyText: Note that toString() in the BibTeX class does not produce "valid" BibTeX in all cases - see the method comment there. - However, in this case, it is fine.
timeline.author: koppor

timeline.bodyText:
Not sure whether this should be closed, too.
I think, however, that closing the inputStream is enough. (Which surely happens somehwere in the code)
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: Good point. Actually, unless I'm missing something, I don't think the inputStream is closed - I will refactor this code so that I make sure to close the inputStream and the reader in a finally block.
replies.author: daniel-price

replies.bodyText:
Typically, one should use the try-with-resoruces feature by Java --> https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/tryResourceClose.html
Could be hard here since the thing is distributed among multiple methods
replies.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: Actually you are correct - they were using try-with-resources for the InputStream. I have used the same pattern for the InputStream I create in my latest commit.
replies.author: daniel-price

timeline.author: koppor
koppor

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the information, I'll make use of streams!
replies.author: daniel-price

timeline.bodyText:
This reminds me of DublinCore. We have support for Dublin Core somehwere in JabRef.
With checking for dc:title, the parser will fail if the XML namespace prefix changes to dc2 or something other than dc.
I think, for the current PR, it's OK. For a future PR, I would be very happy if you digged into the Dublin Core thing.
This is a task where the patience is requested. Deep thinking what's better. Starting point: #938 (comment)
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the information! I've changed the way we do this now to use the existing Bibtex parser, but will bear this in mind for next time.
replies.author: daniel-price

timeline.bodyText:
Could you please use our BibEntry build thingy, here`
bibEntry2 = new BibEntry()
  .withField(...)
  .withField(...)
  ...
We try to use builders whereever possible in the code to make contributors used to it.
timeline.author: koppor

timeline.bodyText:
The tests are a good start. They should cover much more!
I searched for "kopp decker", which gives me following result:

The corresponding BibTeX is the following one:
``bibtex
@Article{journals/dke/DeckerKLW09,
title =	"Interacting services: From specification to
execution",
author =	"Gero Decker and Oliver Kopp and Frank Leymann and
Mathias Weske",
journal =	"Data Knowl. Eng",
year = 	"2009",
number =	"10",
volume =	"68",
bibdate =	"2019-06-02",
bibsource =	"DBLP,
http://dblp.uni-trier.de/https://doi.org/10.1016/j.datak.2009.04.003;
DBLP,
http://dblp.uni-trier.de/https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q59898182;
DBLP,
http://dblp.uni-trier.de/db/journals/dke/dke68.html#DeckerKLW09",
pages =	"946--972",
}

I would expect, title, author, journal, year, number, volume and pages being present in the result. These are all requried fields for a `@article`.

Maybe, even all returend by the "BibTeX" result of CCSB could be shown here?
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText:
Having looked at this a little more, I think I want to slightly change my plan and would like your opinion on it. My understanding is:


Doing a search returns a number of citation results.
e.g. http://liinwww.ira.uka.de/bibliography/rss?query=kopp%20decker&sort=score


Each of these results has a single link which itself has a one or more BibTeX results.
e.g. the first result has a link to http://liinwww.ira.uka.de/searchbib/index?query=hmdtbhgnnqjrcfgprnkqtprfkhdrpqkq&results=bibtex&mode=dup&rss=1


Currently I retrieve the citation results (1), and parse a few fields to generate a BibEntry for each one. I think instead I want to parse just the link from each one, and retrieve the BibTeX results from that link (2). Then I can use the existing BibtexParser to generate a BibEntry for each of those.
Have I understood correctly? Does my new plan sound sensible to you?
Thank you for the feedback!
replies.author: daniel-price

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, sounds perfect! This way, we don't need to convert for ourselves, but use the "intelligence" of the provider!
(And sorry for the delayed reply)
replies.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: Fantastic, thank you. I've reworked this to do the above process instead. Please let me know if you have any other suggestions.
replies.author: daniel-price

timeline.bodyText:
On the one hand, I think, the aim is to be careful when testing and be open to a new format. On the other hand, JabRef decided to test for the concrete format returned by the site. Seeing changes there very often, leads to an early attention of us (and not users showing up complaining that a fetcher does not work; refs #6369)
See https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/test/java/org/jabref/logic/importer/fetcher/INSPIREFetcherTest.java for some examples.
Could you please add these kinds of tests, too?
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: I have changed the tests so that we now check explicitly that each field is as we expect.
replies.author: daniel-price

timeline.message: Make fetcher test more specific by checking each field explicitly

timeline.bodyText:
Would it be possible to remove \t\t  from the abstract?
Can we replace \r\n by the configured newline character (OS.NEWLINE)? --> Use org.jabref.logic.formatter.bibtexfields.NormalizeNewlinesFormatter in a CleanupJob.
org.jabref.logic.formatter.bibtexfields.TrimWhitespaceFormatter cannot be used for the first requriement. Think we need a new TrimWhitespaceAndFixNewLinesInTextFieldFormatter. Would it be possible for you to add such a Formatter?
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText:
I can see that there is also an RemoveNewlinesFormatter - what is the reason for choosing to normalize the new lines rather than remove them? It looks like the new lines were added due for formatting reasons, and were not actually present in the original paper's abstract.
I therefore propose that I use the existing RemoveNewlinesFormatter, and also add a RemoveTabFormatter which removes any instance of \t.
What do you think?
replies.author: daniel-price

replies.bodyText: Yeah, let's see how it works out!
replies.author: koppor

timeline.bodyText: Could you add a comment: "// Checking entries in the set as the query is generic and returns a changing result set"
timeline.author: koppor
koppor
